questions.text: The commonest site of branchial cysts is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Commonest site of Branchial Cyst is between upper 1/3rd and lower 2/3rd of sternocleidomastoid on its anterior border. Commonest site of Branchial fistula is at the junction of upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd of sternocleidomastoid at the anterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle. Branchial Cyst Develops from the vestigial remnants of 2nd branchial cleft Lined by squamous epithelium. It Contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. Cyst usually presents in the upper neck in early or middle adulthood. Fluctuant swelling that may transilluminate and is often soft in its early stages. USG and FNAC aid diagnosis Treatment is by complete excision

choices.text: Commonly seen in high altitude habitants

questions.text: True about carotid body tumor: (PGI June 2004)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C & D) Option C: This is correct as oxygen saturation is less in the air at high altitudes so due to chronic hypoxia there occurs hypertrophy of chromaffin cells in the carotid bulb leading to carotid body tumour. Option D: This is correct as most of the carotid body tumours are sporadic but around 10% have familial association. Option A: This is false as Carotid body tumours arise from carotid body which is situated in the wall of the carotid bulb, which is a present at the carotid bifurcation. Option B: This is false as carotid body tumours do not arise from baroreceptor cells instead they arise from chemoreceptor cells. Carotid body tumours are also referred to as a non chromaffin paraganglioma. Option E: FNAC is not diagnostic, carotid angiography is diagnostic for diagnosing carotid body tumours. FNAC and Biopsy are contraindicated in carotid body tumours.

choices.text: Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Carotid body tumour: (PGI Dec 2005)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D: Carotid body tumour mostly does not spread but it has a tendency of metastasizing to distant organs. Option A and B: This is false as carotid body tumours arise from chemoreceptor cells of the wall of the carotid body. Option C : Radiotherapy is not the treatment of choice, if the patient is elderly we go for observation but if the patient is young we can go for resection of the tumour.

questions.text: Which one is not true regarding carotid body tumour?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D: This is false as the population which is most commonly affected in carotid body tumour is elderly between 6-7 th decade of life. Option A: It is true as most of carotid body tumours are sporadic and unilateral. Option B: Surgical resection is the treatment for carotid body tumour in patients who are young and suffer from carotid body tumour Option C: Carotid body tumour is also referred to as non chromaffin paraganglioma

questions.text: Cystic hygroma is most commonly associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the neck which occurs because of the sequestration of jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly associated with Turner's Syndrome. Chromosomal abnormalities, mainly Turner syndrome, are found in about 50% of cases. Genetic syndromes are found in about 40% of cases. The most common are Noonan syndrome (autosomal dominant but >90% are due to de novo mutations; cystic hygromas, hypertelorism, pulmonary stenosis, fetal growth restriction), Multiple-pterygium syndrome (autosomal recessive; cystic hygromas, contractures in all joints, microcephaly and micrognathia), Fryns syndrome (autosomal recessive; anophthalmia, facial cleft, micrognathia, ventriculomegaly, diaphragmatic hernia) and Neu-Laxova syndrome (autosomal recessive; hypertelorism, microcephaly, agenesis of corpus calosum, contractures in the upper and lower limbs, fetal growth restriction).

choices.text: Present in anterior triangle of neck

questions.text: True about cystic hygroma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C : This is correct as surgical excision is the preferred treatment of cystic hygroma and before taking the patient for surgery you need to delineate the extensions of the sac which can be done on MRI so preoperative MRI is crucial before planning the surgery of cystic hygroma. Option A : Cystic hygroma occurs most commonly in the posterior triangle of neck and not in the anterior triangle. Option B : This statement is false as in cystic hygroma we use sclerosing agents as a form of treatment. Bleomycin and picinabil are the sclerosing agents which are used. Option D: Surgery is the preferred treatment for cystic hygroma but it is not always indicated, in some patients we go for sclerotherapy as a preferred treatment option.

questions.text: Cystic compressible, translucent swelling in the posterior triangle of neck:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A : This is the correct answer as cystic hygroma is the compressible, non reducible, transilluminant swelling occurring in the posterior triangle of the neck. It is caused because of the sequestration of the jugular lymph sac. Option B: Branchial cyst is also a congenital swelling occurring due to defect in the development of the second branchial cleft. It is a swelling which occurs on the anterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle at the junction of upper 1/3 rd and middle 1/3rd. It is usually non translucent and non compressible. Option C : Thyroglossal cyst occurs in the midline. Most common site is subhyoid, it moves with deglutition and swallowing. Option D: Dermoid cyst is a non compressible and non transilluminant swelling.

questions.text: Cystic hygroma is known to occur in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cystic hygroma is a swelling which occurs because of sequestration of the jugular lymph sac. Most common site of cystic hygroma is posterior triangle of neck, but cystic hygroma can occur at other places where the lymphatics occur like axilla and mediastinum. Cystic hygroma does not occur in calf region.

choices.text: Arise from lower third of sternocleidomastoid
Peak age of presentation is 3rd decade
Cyst wall consists of lymphoid tissue

questions.text: True about branchial cyst: (PGI Nov 2011)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B, C, D & E) Option A: This is false as branchial cyst arises from the upper third of sternocleidomastoid muscle not from the lower third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Option B: Peak age of presentation of branchial cyst is 3rd decade Option C : This is true as cyst wall of the branchial cyst is lined by the lymphoid tissue. Option D: This is true as cyst contains a straw coloured fluid which is rich in cholesterol crystals. Option E: Branchial cyst is lined by the squamous epithelium and branchial fistula is lined by the columnar epithelium

questions.text: Commonest treatment of branchial cyst:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Branchial cyst needs excision as a treatment option.

questions.text: The most common site of the internal opening of a branchial fistula is at the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Branchial fistula has two opening, one internal and other one external . External opening of branchial fistula is at the junction of middle and lower 1/3rd at the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Internal opening of the branchial fistula is on the posterior aspect of the faucial pillar in the tonsillar fossa.

questions.text: Excision of the hyoid bone is done in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C : Thyroglossal cyst is a midline swelling which moves with deglutition and protrusion of tongue. Most common site of thyroglossal cyst is sub hyoid. So when we operate a patient of thyroglossal cyst we have to excise the hyoid bone.

questions.text: Which is never a cause of thyroglossal fistula?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Thyroglossal fistula is never a congenital deformity, it is always an acquired condition. Most of the cases occur due to improper removal of the thyroglossal cyst and it may also occur because of the infection of the thyroglossal cyst which might spontaneously rupture to the external atmosphere and lead to the fistula formation.

questions.text: Structures not removed in radical neck dissection:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, C & D) Radical neck dissection was first described by Crile. In Radical neck dissection we remove following structures : Lymph node stations I to V Submandibular salivary gland Spinal accessory nerve Internal Jugular vein Sternocleidomastoid muscle Modified Radical neck dissection Level 1 to 5 lymph node removed but at least one structure is saved . MRND 1 : Spinal accessory nerve MRND 2 : Both spinal accessory nerve and internal jugular vein are saved . MRND 3 : All 3 are saved . (Functional neck dissection)

questions.text: In Post radical neck dissection shoulder syndrome, all are seen except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) As we have removed spinal accessory nerve in radical neck dissection we do not get normal electromyographic finding. In radical neck dissection, the most crippling complication is the “Shoulder syndrome” arising from denervation and atrophy of the trapezius muscle due to sacrifice of the spinal accessory nerve. Shoulder syndrome is characterized by • Inability to abduct the shoulder beyond 90 degree cephalad • Long standing pain in the shoulder • Deformity of the shoulder girdle (drooping of the shoulder with abduction and external rotation)

questions.text: Level V cervical nodes includes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lymph node stations of Neck: Level Ia : Submental Level Ib : Submandibular Level II : Upper Jugular Level III: Middle Jugular Level IV: Lower Jugular (Virchow's Node) Level V: Posterior triangle Level VI : Central group of lymph node (Delphian Node) Level VII: Mediastinal Lymph node

choices.text: Spinal accessory nerve, submandibular salivary gland

questions.text: Structures removed in all types of modified radical neck dissection are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In all types of modified radical neck dissection we remove Lymph nodes I to V and submandibular salivary gland. Depending on which structures we preserve during neck dissection modified radical neck dissection is of 3 types: Type I: We preserve spinal accessory nerve Type II : We preserve spinal accessory nerve and internal jugular vein Type III: We preserve spinal accessory nerve, internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle Type III Neck dissection is also referred to as a functional neck dissection

questions.text: In extended supraomohyoid neck dissection, lymph node dissection is done upto:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lymph nodes stations removed in supraomohyoid neck dissection : Level I, II and III Lymph node stations removed in extended supraomohyoid neck dissection : I, II, III and IV

questions.text: Secondaries in the neck with no obvious primary malignancy is most often due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CA Nasopharynx tends to spread to the lateral neck lymph nodes and this is the most common first presentation of Ca Nasopharynx. If this happens there will be a lateral neck mass with no signs of primary malignancy. Option A : Stomach Ca in later stages can present as a neck lymph node enlargement. Enlarged lymph node is called virchow's lymph node and this sign is called as a troisier's sign . Option B: Ca Larynx presents as a hoarseness of voice or pain or stridor depending on which part of larynx is involved Option D . Ca thyroid specially papillary ca is notorious in presenting as lateral aberrant thyroid nodule but in this we will also have enlargement of thyroid gland which is a midline neck swelling.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with a firm non mobile pulsatile mass in neck. Imaging shows the following finding. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In this figure we see the typical lyre sign. The lyre sign refers to the splaying of the internal and external carotid by a carotid body tumour. Classically described on angiography it is also visible on CT angiography. It is typically seen in carotid body tumour also known as potato tumour

questions.text: Carotid artery blowout is associated with which procedure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Carotid blowout syndrome (CBS) is a rare but life-threatening complication of head and neck cancer. Most commonly, patients have a history of squamous cell carcinoma and have undergone prior radical neck surgery and radiation therapy. Bleeding from the oral cavity and from an exposed neck wound are the common symptoms. Advances in interventional radiology have made management of these conditions possible which was difficult earlier. Still prognosis is poor and mortality rate is 40 to 60 %.

questions.text: Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap is based on which artery ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The pectoralis major myocutaneous flap (PMMF) is useful in head and neck reconstruction. The PMMF is mainly supplied by perforators of the pectoral branch of the thoracoacromial artery which runs on the underside of the PM.

questions.text: Delphian lymph node is which level of neck lymph node ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Level VI : Delphian lymph node Level IV: Virchow's lymph node

questions.text: Moure’s sign is seen in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Moure’s sign: in normal persons, there is a click felt when the larynx is moved from side to side over the vertebral column. This sign is absent in patients with post-cricoid carcinoma (Moure’s sign positive)
